text: How can you decide when a ratio is comparing a part to a part? A part to a whole? How can you decide when two ratios are equivalent?

Students should have a deeper understanding and recognition of various forms for ratio comparison statements. Students should be able to recognize when they are comparing two different quantities and when they are comparing a part to the total.

  • Ratio comparisons can be written as part-to-part and as part-to-whole comparisons.
  • The context of the problem and how the ratio statement is written helps to determine if it is a part-to-part or part-to-whole comparison. In our problem of the cupcakes, for example, we have either green or white cupcakes. Ratio statements that compare green to white cupcakes would be considered part-to-part. Ratio statements that compare the number of green cupcakes to the total number of cupcakes would be part-to-whole.
  • A ratio is written as a part-to-part comparison when it compares "some" to "some."
  • A ratio is written as a part-to-whole comparison when it compares "some" to "all."
  • Ratios with the same (multiplicative) relationship between the quantities are equivalent ratios.
  • The order of the ratio statement does not matter as long as the quantities are labeled correctly.

Note: This might be the time to explore whether an additive comparison or a multiplicative comparison is more helpful.
